results.title: Nara: a stroll through history
results.creator_credit: Shin Nippon and Shu Taguchi Productions
results.brief_description: The first of Japan’s capitals built in the middle of the sixth century, Nara is one of the country’s most ancient cities. It is a great temple with broad avenues and many fine buildings. The capital was moved to Kyoto, but Nara is still known as the “cradle of Japanese culture”.

results.title: Naqoyqatsi: life as war
results.creator_credit: Godfrey Reggio, Joe Beirne, Lawrence Taub and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: The last of a trilogy that consists of “Koyaanisqatsi” (1982) and “Powaqqatsi” (1988) by Godfrey Reggio. In this instalment Reggio addresses the effect that technology has on our lives and the detrimental impact of advertising, media and technology to create a life out of balance. Music score by Phillip Glass. Director Steven Soderbergh served as executive producer.

results.title: Napoli
results.creator_credit: Kirsten Ralov, Preben Montell, Danmarks Radio and National Video Corporation
results.brief_description: Performed by the Royal Danish Ballet at the Royal Theatre, Copenhagen, “Napoli” is a ballet in three acts by 19th century dancer and choreographer, August Bournonville with music by E. Helsted, G. Rossini, Niels W. Gade, H.S. Paulli, H.C. Lumbye. It is a romantic tale of a young fisherman, Gennaro (Arne Villumsen) and his beloved Teresina (Linda Hindberg) set in the delightful Italian seaside town of Naples. Supporting cast includes Mona Jensen, Flemming Ryberg, Fredbjorn Bjornsson, Tommy Frishoi, Palle Jacobsen with the Royal Danish Orchestra conducted by Peter Ernst Lassen.

results.title: Napoleon: the making of a dictator
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas, International Film Associates and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Portrays the kind of political and social chaos from which dictators draw their strength, and shows how military victories built Napoleon’s popularity.

results.title: Napoleon (2000) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: David Grubin and David Grubin Productions
results.brief_description: Details the life and times of an intriguing historical figure, Napoleon Bonaparte, his rise to military power and highs and lows of a colourful life at a time of great social upheaval in Europe. Episode 1. “To destiny” - Recounts the story of Napoleon’s extraordinary rise from the obscurity of his Corsican childhood to famous victories in Italy. Also tells of his love for Josephine Beauharnais. Episode 2. “Mastering luck” - Charts Napoleon’s ascent to absolute power from victorious General to first Consol to Emperor of France. Episode 3. “The Summit of ambition” - Traces Napoleon’s conquest of most of Europe including the Battle of Austerlitz and an ambitious invasion of Spain. Episode 4. “The End” - Describes Napoleon’s downfall, including the invasion and subsequent retreat from Russia, his time in exile and his defeat at Waterloo. Fascinating work features historical documentation, stills and re-enactments, as well as interviews with contemporary scholars. Narrated by David McCullough. In English and French with occasional English subtitles.

results.title: Nanook of the North [Silent]
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty, Films Incorporated and Pathe Exchange
results.brief_description: Robert Flaherty was commissioned by the Revillon Fur Company to make an advertising film, and the result of his visit to the Hudson Bay territory of Canada was “Nanook of the North”. It is difficult to realise that Flaherty had to work entirely alone and without the advantages of panchromatic stock. His use of realist material to present not a story but rather a dramatic theme of man’s struggle with his environment opened up a new realm of film-making. It was the first documentary film in the modern sense. The film shows Nanook, the Eskimo hunter, preparing with his family for the summer, his meeting with the white trader, catching walruses, seals and foxes, building an igloo, training his children in the arts of hunting, breaking camp, and finally returning through a wild storm to safety and rest in an old igloo.

results.title: Names of sin
results.creator_credit: Rolf Forsberg, Karl Holtsnider, Franciscan Communications Centre and Teleketics
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a nine-year-old girl Missy who is persuaded by her peers to throw a stone at an old lady. She later discovers that the old lady is dying and a personal awareness of having done an unloving act weighs heavily upon her. Her mother’s loving response to her torment and instinctive gestures of consolation even as she lets Missy know the seriousness of her action, frees Missy and she finds her own special way to express her sorrow. The dramatic tension traces the dynamics of the sacrament of Penance, as Missy experiences sorrow, guilt and the peace that comes with forgiveness.

results.title: Namekas: music in Lake Chambri
results.brief_description: Deals principally with the spiritual references that music has for the Lake Chambri people, featuring the sacred talking flutes that are played and seen only by men. Shows also songs of ceremonial and everyday nature, and other instruments, including the “talking” slit drums, panpipes, and a most unusual instrument in the form of a sago beetle. Produced with assistance from Australian Film Commission, Australia Council, Dept. Foreign Affairs and PNG National Cultural Council.
